rules.rule_text_en: Many verbs are followed by to + infinitive (want, decide, hope, plan).
rules.rule_text_uk: Багато дієслів уживаються з to + інфінітивом (want, decide, hope, plan).
examples: We hope to see you soon.

rules.rule_text_en: Some verbs can be followed by question words + to (what to do, how to get there).
rules.rule_text_uk: Деякі дієслова можуть мати після себе питальне слово + to (what to do, how to get there).
examples: I don’t know what to say.
Can you show me how to use it?

rules.rule_text_en: After would like / would love / would prefer we use to + infinitive.
rules.rule_text_uk: Після would like / would love / would prefer уживаємо to + інфінітив.
examples: I’d like to speak to the manager.
I’d prefer to stay at home.

rules.rule_text_en: Some verbs are followed by -ing (enjoy, mind, avoid, finish).
rules.rule_text_uk: Після деяких дієслів уживаємо -ing (enjoy, mind, avoid, finish).

rules.rule_text_en: After prepositions we normally use -ing: interested in doing, good at doing.
rules.rule_text_uk: Після прийменників зазвичай -ing: interested in doing, good at doing.

rules.rule_text_en: Go + -ing is used for activities: go shopping, go swimming, go running.
rules.rule_text_uk: Go + -ing уживають для занять: go shopping, go swimming, go running.

rules.rule_text_en: Some verbs take an object + to + infinitive: want/ask/tell/expect someone to do.
rules.rule_text_uk: Деякі дієслова мають додаток + to + інфінітив: want/ask/tell/expect someone to do.
examples: We expect them to arrive soon.

rules.rule_text_en: Some verbs use object + infinitive without to (make/let/help in some patterns).
rules.rule_text_uk: З деякими дієсловами інфінітив без to: make/let (інколи help).

rules.rule_text_en: Ask/tell/order/advise + object + to is common in requests and instructions.
rules.rule_text_uk: Ask/tell/order/advise + додаток + to часто вживають у проханнях та інструкціях.
examples: I asked her to call me.
The doctor advised me to rest.

rules.rule_text_en: Some verbs can be followed by -ing or to with a change in meaning (stop, remember, try).
rules.rule_text_uk: Деякі дієслова можуть мати -ing або to з різницею значення (stop, remember, try).
examples: Stop to smoke. (stop in order to smoke)

rules.rule_text_en: Remember/forget + to = do it; remember/forget + -ing = memory of a past action.
rules.rule_text_uk: Remember/forget + to = зробити; remember/forget + -ing = спогад про минулу дію.
rules.rule_short_en: Remember to do vs remember doing.
rules.rule_short_uk: Пам’ятати зробити vs пам’ятати, що робив.

rules.rule_text_en: Try + to = attempt; try + -ing = experiment to see what happens.
rules.rule_text_uk: Try + to = спробувати (зусилля); try + -ing = спробувати як експеримент.
rules.rule_short_en: Try to do vs try doing.
examples: I tried to open the window.
He tried talking to her calmly.

rules.rule_text_en: We use to + infinitive to say the purpose: I went out to buy food.
rules.rule_text_uk: To + інфінітив уживають, щоб показати мету: I went out to buy food.
examples: I came here to ask a question.

rules.rule_text_en: In order to / so as to are more formal ways to express purpose; negatives: in order not to / so as not to.
rules.rule_text_uk: In order to / so as to — більш офіційно для мети; заперечення: in order not to / so as not to.
examples: He spoke quietly in order not to wake the baby.
I moved closer so as to hear better.
She left early in order to catch the train.

rules.rule_text_en: For + noun can express purpose (a thing): a tool for cutting, a room for meetings.
rules.rule_text_uk: For + іменник може виражати призначення: a tool for cutting, a room for meetings.
rules.rule_short_en: For + noun = purpose of a thing.
examples: This key is for the back door.
We need a place for parking.

rules.rule_text_en: After some adjectives we use to + infinitive: easy to do, difficult to understand, happy to help.
rules.rule_text_uk: Після деяких прикметників уживаємо to + інфінітив: easy to do, difficult to understand, happy to help.

rules.rule_text_en: We often use it + adjective + to: It’s nice to see you. It was impossible to park.
rules.rule_text_uk: Часто вживаємо it + прикметник + to: It’s nice to see you. It was impossible to park.

rules.rule_text_en: With adjectives like surprised/glad/sorry, we can use that-clause or to-clause: I’m glad to see you / glad that you came.
rules.rule_text_uk: З прикметниками surprised/glad/sorry можливе that-підрядне або to: glad to see you / glad that you came.
examples: She was surprised that he left.

rules.rule_text_en: After prepositions we use -ing: before leaving, without saying, by doing.
rules.rule_text_uk: Після прийменників уживаємо -ing: before leaving, without saying, by doing.

rules.rule_text_en: Verb + preposition + -ing is common: apologise for doing, succeed in doing, insist on doing.
rules.rule_text_uk: Поширено: дієслово + прийменник + -ing: apologise for doing, succeed in doing, insist on doing.

rules.rule_text_en: To is also a preposition in be used to / look forward to, so it is followed by -ing.
rules.rule_text_uk: To також може бути прийменником у be used to / look forward to, тому після нього -ing.
rules.rule_short_en: Be used to / look forward to + -ing.
rules.rule_short_uk: Be used to / look forward to + -ing.
examples: I’m used to getting up early.
I look forward to seeing you.

rules.rule_text_en: We can use -ing as a subject: Swimming is good for you. Reading helps you relax.
rules.rule_text_uk: -ing може бути підметом: Swimming is good for you. Reading helps you relax.

rules.rule_text_en: We can use -ing after be to talk about a job/activity: My hobby is collecting stamps.
rules.rule_text_uk: -ing після be може описувати заняття/роботу: My hobby is collecting stamps.
examples: The best thing is getting started.

rules.rule_text_en: After no point / worth / busy, we often use -ing: It’s worth doing. There’s no point arguing.
rules.rule_text_uk: Після no point / worth / busy часто -ing: It’s worth doing. There’s no point arguing.

rules.rule_text_en: Be used to means 'accustomed to' and is followed by a noun or -ing: I’m used to getting up early.
rules.rule_text_uk: Be used to означає «звиклий» і має після себе іменник або -ing: I’m used to getting up early.
examples: We’re not used to this noise.

rules.rule_text_en: Get used to means 'become accustomed to' (a change over time).
rules.rule_text_uk: Get used to означає «звикати» (процес).
examples: You’ll get used to the traffic.
He’s getting used to his new job.
It took me weeks to get used to it.

rules.rule_text_en: Used to (without be/get) means a past habit/state: I used to live there. (different meaning).
rules.rule_text_uk: Used to (без be/get) означає звичку/стан у минулому: I used to live there. (інше значення).
examples: We used to live in Odesa.

rules.rule_text_en: Prefer can be followed by -ing or to + infinitive: I prefer walking / I prefer to walk.
rules.rule_text_uk: Prefer може мати -ing або to + інфінітив: I prefer walking / I prefer to walk.
examples: She prefers to travel by train.

rules.rule_text_en: Would rather + infinitive without to: I’d rather stay in. Negative: would rather not.
rules.rule_text_uk: Would rather + інфінітив без to: I’d rather stay in. Заперечення: would rather not.
examples: I’d rather not talk about it.

rules.rule_text_en: Would rather + past (about someone else) for present/future: I’d rather you didn’t smoke.
rules.rule_text_uk: Would rather + past (про іншу особу) для теперішнього/майбутнього: I’d rather you didn’t smoke.
rules.rule_short_uk: Я б волів, щоб ти (не) робив…
examples: Would you rather I called later?
